intro: Abutilon longipes, commonly known as the long-stemmed abutilon, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 5 meters tall, characterized by its hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, yellow flowers that bloom in the spring and summer. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds, and it is often found in moist, tropical environments. Abutilon longipes is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon longipes is primarily native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly Brazil and Peru. It thrives in humid, warm climates and is commonly found in lowland rainforests and along riverbanks. This species is also present in parts of northern Argentina and Ecuador. It prefers well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight. Due to its ornamental value, it has been introduced to other tropical regions around the world.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon longipes was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It is commonly found in moist, temperate forests and along stream banks. This plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its attractive, lantern-shaped leaves. It has become naturalized in several areas, sometimes competing with native vegetation. However, it is generally considered a non-invasive species in its introduced range.
